subject: English
note: EnglishUnit nodes for KS1 (Y1-Y2). Genre-based units following the NC requirement for pupils to 'write for a range of purposes' including stories, poetry, recounts, and instructions. Grammar focus draws from NC Appendix 2 (Y1 and Y2 statutory grammar). Each unit has a writing_outcome as the single most important property.

units.name: Traditional Tales: The Three Billy Goats Gruff
units.subject: English
curriculum_reference: Reading - Comprehension (Y1): listening to and discussing a wide range of poems, stories and non-fiction
Writing - Composition (Y1): write sentences by sequencing sentences to form short narratives
text_features_to_teach: rule of three (three goats, three attempts)
units.writing_outcome: Retell the story in 4-6 sentences using the repeated refrain and sequencing words (first, then, next, finally)
units.spoken_language_outcome: Retell the story orally using a story map, with appropriate expression for different characters

suggested_texts.title: The Three Billy Goats Gruff
suggested_texts.author: Traditional (various illustrators)
suggested_texts.note: Use a version with clear, large illustrations for shared reading

units.pedagogical_rationale: Traditional tales are the entry point to narrative at KS1. The Three Billy Goats Gruff is ideal for Y1 because its repetitive structure, limited cast, and clear conflict support oral retelling before written retelling. The rule of three provides a scaffolding structure that Y1 children can internalise and replicate.
common_pitfalls: Spending too long on drama and retelling without moving to written output
Not explicitly teaching the story structure (beginning, middle, end) as a transferable pattern
Writing task too ambitious for Y1 — keep to 4-6 sentences

units.name: Traditional Tales: Little Red Riding Hood
units.subject: English
curriculum_reference: Reading - Comprehension (Y1): becoming very familiar with key stories, fairy stories and traditional tales, retelling them and considering their particular characteristics
Writing - Composition (Y1): write sentences by sequencing sentences to form short narratives
text_features_to_teach: character descriptions (big bad wolf, little girl)
direct speech pattern (What big eyes you have!)
moral lesson (do not talk to strangers)
units.writing_outcome: Write own version of a familiar story changing one element (character, setting or ending) in 5-8 sentences
units.spoken_language_outcome: Perform the dialogue between Red Riding Hood and the wolf with expression and character voices

suggested_texts.title: Little Red Riding Hood
suggested_texts.author: Traditional (various illustrators)
suggested_texts.note: Use alongside a modern retelling for comparison

suggested_texts.title: Little Red
suggested_texts.author: Bethan Woollvin
suggested_texts.note: Modern feminist retelling — strong female protagonist

units.pedagogical_rationale: Building on the first traditional tale unit, this unit introduces changing one story element as a scaffold to independent composition. Y1 children can manage changing the setting, the character, or the ending while retaining the familiar structure. The dialogue pattern (What big X you have!) is highly memorable and supports early speech punctuation awareness.
common_pitfalls: Pupils copy the original rather than innovating their own version
Character change is superficial (just changing the name) rather than meaningful
Drama work does not feed into the writing task

units.name: Instructions: How to Wash a Woolly Mammoth
units.subject: English
curriculum_reference: Writing - Composition (Y1): writing clearly, using basic punctuation
Writing - Vocabulary, Grammar and Punctuation (Y1): sequencing sentences to form short narratives
units.writing_outcome: Write a set of instructions (5-6 steps) for a simple task using numbered steps, imperative verbs, and sequencing words

suggested_texts.title: How to Wash a Woolly Mammoth
suggested_texts.author: Michelle Robinson
suggested_texts.note: Humorous instruction text that models the form while entertaining

units.pedagogical_rationale: Instruction writing is one of the most accessible non-fiction forms at KS1 because its structure is concrete and visual (numbered steps, imperative verbs). Using a humorous text as the model engages children while teaching the genuine features of the form. The task of writing real instructions that someone else follows provides authentic purpose.
common_pitfalls: Instructions lack sufficient detail for someone to actually follow them
Steps are not in logical order
Pupils write in narrative rather than instructional register

cross_curricular_links.hook: Writing instructions for a making task

units.name: Poetry: Nursery Rhymes and Rhyming Poems
units.subject: English
curriculum_reference: Reading - Comprehension (Y1): learning to appreciate rhymes and poems, and to recite some by heart
Spoken Language: use spoken language to develop understanding through speculating, hypothesising, imagining and exploring ideas
units.writing_outcome: Write a simple rhyming poem (4-8 lines) following a pattern from a model poem, choosing own rhyming words
units.spoken_language_outcome: Recite at least 2 poems by heart with appropriate expression, pace, and volume
grammar_focus: full stops or no punctuation (following the model)

suggested_texts.title: A Great Big Cuddle
suggested_texts.author: Michael Rosen
suggested_texts.note: Accessible, playful poems ideal for performance

units.pedagogical_rationale: Poetry is the first literary form most children encounter through nursery rhymes. At Y1, the focus is on enjoyment, recitation, and pattern recognition. Rhyming poems develop phonological awareness (hearing sounds in words) which supports phonics. Writing a simple rhyming poem using a pattern from a model is achievable and builds confidence with creative composition.
common_pitfalls: Focus on writing poems before children have heard and recited enough models
Expecting rhyming couplets when children have not yet developed sufficient phonological repertoire
Performance reduced to mumbled group recitation rather than expressive individual delivery

cross_curricular_links.hook: Rhythm and beat in poetry — clapping rhythms, musical accompaniment

units.name: Recount: My Weekend
units.subject: English
curriculum_reference: Writing - Composition (Y1): writing about real events
Writing - Vocabulary, Grammar and Punctuation (Y1): using the past tense correctly
units.writing_outcome: Write a personal recount (4-6 sentences) in chronological order using past tense and time words
grammar_focus: past tense (regular: played, walked; irregular: went, saw)

suggested_texts.title: Model recount (teacher-written)
suggested_texts.author: Teacher
suggested_texts.note: Teacher models writing own recount on the board, thinking aloud about time words and past tense

units.pedagogical_rationale: Personal recount is the simplest non-fiction form because children write about their own experience — they already know the content and sequence. This makes it ideal for teaching text structure (chronological order) and grammar (past tense) without the cognitive load of inventing content. Oral rehearsal (Tell your partner about your weekend) precedes writing.
common_pitfalls: Every sentence begins with 'Then I...' without varying openings
Recount is a list of events without specific detail or personal response
Past tense inconsistency (mixing went and go within the same piece)

units.name: Narrative: Dogger
units.subject: English
curriculum_reference: Writing - Composition (Y2): write narratives about personal experiences and those of others (real and fictional)
Writing - Vocabulary, Grammar and Punctuation (Y2): expanded noun phrases, co-ordination and subordination
units.writing_outcome: Write an original narrative (8-12 sentences) about losing and finding something precious, using a clear problem-resolution structure with expanded noun phrases
grammar_focus: expanded noun phrases (the old, brown teddy)

suggested_texts.title: Dogger
suggested_texts.author: Shirley Hughes
suggested_texts.note: Classic text with clear emotional arc and problem-resolution structure

suggested_texts.title: Knuffle Bunny
suggested_texts.author: Mo Willems
suggested_texts.note: Alternative lost-and-found narrative with photographic illustration

units.pedagogical_rationale: Dogger provides a perfect model for Y2 narrative because its emotional arc is universally relatable (losing a beloved toy) and its structure is transparent. The five-part narrative structure (beginning, build-up, problem, resolution, ending) gives pupils a clear framework that is more sophisticated than KS1 beginning-middle-end but still manageable. The expanded noun phrases needed to describe the toy connect reading and grammar naturally.
common_pitfalls: Pupils write about their own lost toy experience as a recount rather than as a structured narrative
Problem is resolved too quickly without building tension
Expanded noun phrases used only in the opening rather than throughout

cross_curricular_links.hook: Drawing and describing a treasured possession using expanded noun phrases

units.name: Information Text: All About Animals
units.subject: English
curriculum_reference: Reading - Comprehension (Y2): being introduced to non-fiction books that are structured in different ways
Writing - Composition (Y2): writing for different purposes including about real events
units.writing_outcome: Write a simple non-chronological report (6-10 sentences) about an animal with a title, subheadings, factual sentences in present tense, and a labelled diagram

suggested_texts.title: DK My First Animal Encyclopedia
suggested_texts.author: DK
suggested_texts.note: Clear non-fiction layout with subheadings, diagrams, and facts

suggested_texts.title: National Geographic Little Kids First Big Book of Animals
suggested_texts.author: Catherine D. Hughes
suggested_texts.note: Accessible animal facts with excellent photographs

units.pedagogical_rationale: Non-chronological reports about animals are the standard entry point to information writing at KS1 because children are naturally interested in animals and already have background knowledge. The cross-curricular link to Science (living things, habitats) provides authentic content. The structured layout (title, subheadings, facts) teaches organisational skills transferable to all non-fiction writing.
common_pitfalls: Children copy facts verbatim from the source rather than putting them in their own words
Subheadings used decoratively rather than to organise information into categories
Present tense inconsistency (mixing 'Lions live in Africa' with 'The lion lived in a den')

cross_curricular_links.hook: Where animals live in the world
Using digital tools for simple research

units.name: Poetry: Silly Poems and Tongue Twisters
units.subject: English
curriculum_reference: Reading - Comprehension (Y2): continuing to build up a repertoire of poems learnt by heart
Writing - Composition (Y2): writing poetry
units.writing_outcome: Write at least 2 poems: one alliterative tongue twister and one rhyming poem using a pattern from a model, then perform one to the class
units.spoken_language_outcome: Perform a poem to the class with expression, appropriate pace, and clear diction

suggested_texts.title: Oi Frog!
suggested_texts.author: Kes Gray
suggested_texts.note: Rhyming text with word play — can be used as poetry springboard

suggested_texts.title: Poems to Perform
suggested_texts.author: Julia Donaldson
suggested_texts.note: Curated for performance with actions and audience participation

units.pedagogical_rationale: Y2 poetry builds on Y1 recitation by introducing alliteration and more varied forms. Silly poems and tongue twisters engage reluctant writers because the emphasis is on word play and sound rather than narrative coherence. Alliteration develops phonological awareness and vocabulary simultaneously. The performance element fulfils the statutory spoken language requirement.
common_pitfalls: Alliterative poems become lists of words rather than meaningful sentences
Performance is flat group recitation rather than individual expressive delivery
Children struggle with rhyme because they have not heard enough rhyming poetry read aloud

cross_curricular_links.hook: Rhythm in poetry — clapping syllables, adding musical accompaniment

units.name: Traditional Tales: The Enormous Turnip
units.subject: English
curriculum_reference: Reading - Comprehension (Y2): discussing the sequence of events in books and how items of information are related
Writing - Composition (Y2): writing narratives about personal experiences and those of others
text_features_to_teach: cumulative structure (adding characters one by one)
writing from a different character's perspective
units.writing_outcome: Write own cumulative story (10-15 sentences) with a repeated pattern and at least 4 characters, using co-ordination and subordination

suggested_texts.title: The Enormous Turnip
suggested_texts.author: Traditional (Aleksei Tolstoy version)
suggested_texts.note: Classic cumulative structure with clear pattern for innovating

suggested_texts.title: Handa's Surprise
suggested_texts.author: Eileen Browne
suggested_texts.note: Alternative cumulative text with multicultural setting

units.pedagogical_rationale: The Enormous Turnip extends traditional tale study at Y2 by introducing a cumulative structure (each new character joins the pulling chain). This pattern is highly scaffolded — children see the formula, internalise it, and can innovate by changing the object, setting, or characters. It also introduces writing from a different character's perspective, a Y2 composition skill.
common_pitfalls: Innovation is too close to the original (just changing character names)
Cumulative pattern abandoned halfway through, reverting to linear narrative
Subordination used only in teacher-modelled sentences, not in independent writing

units.name: Recount: Diary of a Killer Cat
units.subject: English
curriculum_reference: Writing - Composition (Y2): writing about real events, writing for different purposes
Reading - Comprehension (Y2): discussing and clarifying the meanings of words
text_features_to_teach: diary format (Dear Diary, date, first person)
units.writing_outcome: Write a diary entry (8-12 sentences) from a character's perspective using first person, past tense, diary conventions, and personal opinion

suggested_texts.title: The Diary of a Killer Cat
suggested_texts.author: Anne Fine
suggested_texts.note: Hilarious diary from the cat's perspective — ideal for modelling voice and opinion in recount

suggested_texts.title: Diary of a Wombat
suggested_texts.author: Jackie French
suggested_texts.note: Simpler diary format for lower-ability scaffold

units.pedagogical_rationale: Diary writing from a character's perspective bridges fiction and non-fiction: it uses recount conventions (chronological, past tense, time phrases) but requires imagination (adopting the character's voice and viewpoint). The Diary of a Killer Cat provides a strong, humorous model of personal voice that Y2 children can emulate. This prepares pupils for writing in role at KS2.
common_pitfalls: Diary entry reads as a flat recount without personal voice or opinion
Children write as themselves rather than staying in character
Time phrases (first, then, next) used mechanically without varying openings
